_exec_summary.SummaryText:
November 15, 2005

Kinder Morgan Operating LP ?C? is a subsidiary of Kinder Morgan Terminals and operator of the facility, which was acquired on July 15, 2005, from Terra Nitrogen, L.P., a subsidiary of Terra Industries Inc, who was the previous owner/operator of the facility. 

The Terra Nitrogen, L.P. Blytheville facility was previously operated as a manufacturer of nitrogenous fertilizers.  On May 27, 2004, the manufacturing plants were permanently shut down and the facility converted to a Terminal operation for storage, loading, and unloading of nitrogenous fertilizers from other locations. Although Terra Nitrogen, L.P. changed status from a manufacturing plant to a terminal, the facility (including the barge loading/unloading dock) has been in operation since 1965.

Currently, the facility stores Anhydrous Ammonia above threshold quantities and therefore subject to RMP regulations.  

It is Kinder Morgan?s policy to prevent accidental releases from the terminal by effective process safety management (PSM) programs and procedures.  Kinder Morgan requires participation by terminal employees in every element of the PSM program.

One way Kinder Morgan prevents incidents is by conducting regular analysis of process hazards utilizing current operating and accurate process safety information.  The operations personnel draft and maintain current operating procedures.  Kinder Morgan provides timely and comprehensive training for all employees involved in operating and maintaining process equipment.  It is our policy to oversee the activities of contractors and ensure that they are trained to perform their jobs safely.  We follow established pre-startup safety reviews and management of change procedures to ensure that modifications are adequately evaluated for safety and administer a comprehensive mechanical integrity program to ensure that process equipment is maintained in accordance with good engineering practice and accepted industry standards.  We immediately invest

igate incidents when they do occur so that we promptly correct deficiencies and learn from the experience.

It is our policy to maintain a current and accurate written emergency response plan and a well-trained and equipped onsite emergency response team.  A system is maintained to notify neighbors in the event of a release.  Periodically, we coordinate emergency response planning with local authorities and participate in joint exercises.  On a regular basis, the PSM program is audited to verify that elements, procedures, and systems are in place and adequate.

Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Kinder Morgan Blytheville terminal has a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals found at 29 CFR Part 1910.779.  Key elements of the PSM program include: 1) stringent design standards of equipment which incorporate substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation; 2) extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel; 4) written operating, maintenance, and safe work procedures; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures; 7) periodic, detailed evaluation of the process area by a team utilizing HazOp methodology; and 8) regular audits of the PSM program; and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program.

Five Year Accident History:
There have been no accidental releases from covered processes at the Blytheville facility within the past five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Emergency Response Team:
The Blytheville facility also has a comprehensive Emergency Response Program which incl

udes a written plan that is coordinated with local authorities, an onsite emergency response team, an emergency notification system that utilizes both a terminal area alarm, and the Community Alert Network telephone system.

Terminal personnel have participated in county-wide emergency drills with local responders including the Mississippi County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the Blytheville Fire Department, the Mississippi County Rescue Squad, and personnel from the Blytheville Hospital. Additionally, the terminal exercises its emergency response regularly with in-terminal drills.
